content.content: Security monitoring isn't about watching screens constantly - it's about knowing what to look for and how to respond when something happens. Since we're a small team, we need to be smart about what we monitor and how we handle incidents.
Not every log entry is a security event. Focus on patterns and behaviors that could indicate real threats to our AWS infrastructure or Google Drive data.

items: **Unauthorized access attempts**: Multiple failed logins, access from unusual locations, attempts to access resources without permissions
**Unusual system behavior**: Unexpected CPU/memory spikes, new processes running, unexpected network connections, configuration files being modified
**Configuration changes**: Unauthorized modifications to security groups, IAM policies, system settings, or application configurations
**Failed authentication patterns**: Brute force attempts, credential stuffing, unusual timing of login attempts (like 3 AM from multiple IPs)

content.title: Real vs. Noise
content.content: A single failed login? Probably someone mistyping. Ten failed logins in 30 seconds from different IPs? That's an event worth investigating.
When something suspicious happens, your first instinct might be to fix it immediately. Stop. Preserve evidence first, then remediate. Future you (and potentially FedRAMP auditors) will thank you.

items: **System logs**: CloudTrail logs, application logs, system logs - capture everything from at least 24 hours before the event
**Network data**: VPC Flow Logs, load balancer logs, any firewall or WAF logs
**System state**: Running processes, network connections, user sessions at the time of the event
**Configuration snapshots**: Current security group rules, IAM policies, system configurations
**Screenshots**: If you're seeing something unusual in a console or dashboard, screenshot it immediately
**Don't modify original logs**: Export copies to a separate S3 bucket with versioning enabled
**Document everything**: Create a timeline of what you observed and what actions you took
**Use read-only access**: When investigating, use read-only credentials when possible to avoid accidentally changing evidence
**Calculate checksums**: For critical files, generate MD5 or SHA256 hashes to prove they haven't been modified

content.title: Quick Evidence Preservation
content.content:
```bash
# Export CloudTrail logs
aws s3 sync s3://your-cloudtrail-bucket/AWSLogs/ ./incident-evidence/cloudtrail/

# Generate checksums
find ./incident-evidence -type f -exec sha256sum {} \; > evidence-checksums.txt

# Document the incident
echo "$(date): Started evidence collection for suspected breach" >> incident-timeline.txt
```
FedRAMP has specific requirements for how quickly we need to fix vulnerabilities. These aren't suggestions - they're requirements that can affect our authorization.

items: **Monthly scanning**: Run Amazon Inspector on all EC2 instances and ZAP on web applications
**Document results**: Keep scan reports for at least 1 year
**Track remediation**: Maintain a log of what was found and what was fixed
**Critical vulnerabilities**: Must be fixed within 15 days
**High-Risk vulnerabilities**: Must be fixed within 30 days
**Moderate-Risk vulnerabilities**: Must be fixed within 90 days
**Low-Risk vulnerabilities**: Must be fixed within 180 days

content.title: No Extensions
content.content: These timelines are non-negotiable. If you can't patch within the timeline (15/30/90/180 days for Critical/High/Moderate/Low), you need to implement compensating controls and document why. For CISA KEV vulnerabilities, the 21-day timeline cannot be extended.

The CISA Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog lists vulnerabilities being actively exploited in the wild. **If a vulnerability appears in the KEV catalog, it must be remediated within 21 days regardless of severity rating.**

items: Check the KEV catalog weekly at: https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog
KEV vulnerabilities must be remediated within 21 days, no exceptions
Document when you checked and what actions you took

content.content: Once a year, our independent assessor (ScaleSec) will run their own vulnerability scans. This isn't a surprise - schedule it during a maintenance window and be prepared to fix any findings quickly.
When an incident happens, communication is critical. Poor communication can turn a minor incident into a major problem, especially with FedRAMP reporting requirements.

items: **Immediate notification**: Pete and Savvy must be notified within 15 minutes of discovering a potential incident
**Status updates**: Every hour during active incidents, even if it's "still investigating"
**Clear handoffs**: If you need to step away, explicitly hand off to someone else with a status summary
**Single source of truth**: Use our incident Slack channel for all updates - no side conversations

content.title: Good Incident Communication
content.content:
**2:15 PM**: Detected unusual API activity - 500+ requests/second from single IP to patient lookup endpoint. Investigating.

**2:18 PM**: Blocked IP at WAF level. Activity stopped. Reviewing CloudTrail for any successful requests.

**2:45 PM**: Confirmed no data was accessed. IP traced to known scanner. Updating WAF rules to prevent similar attacks.

**3:15 PM**: Incident resolved. WAF rules updated, no data exposure. Will monitor for next 24 hours.
FedRAMP has strict incident reporting requirements. Missing these deadlines can result in losing our authorization.

items: **Within 1 hour of discovery**: Report significant cyber incidents to FedRAMP PMO (not just data breaches)
**Within 24 hours**: Submit initial incident report for any security incident
**Within 5 days**: Provide detailed incident analysis and remediation plan
**Monthly**: Include all incidents in continuous monitoring report

content.title: When in Doubt, Report
content.content: If you're unsure whether something qualifies as a reportable incident, treat it as one. It's better to over-report than to miss a requirement. Pete makes the final call on FedRAMP notifications.

content.title: Remember: Speed vs. Accuracy
content.content: During an incident, you'll feel pressure to fix things fast. But FedRAMP values accurate reporting and proper evidence preservation. Take the extra 5 minutes to document what you're seeing before you start fixing. Your future self (and our auditors) will appreciate it.
